context: Four boys—Fred, Juan, Marc, and Paul—and three girls—Nita, Rachel, and Trisha—will be assigned to a row of five adjacent lockers, numbered consecutively 1 through 5, arranged along a straight wall. The following conditions govern the assignment of lockers to the seven children: Each locker must be assigned to either one or two children, and each child must be assigned to exactly one locker. Each shared locker must be assigned to one girl and one boy. Juan must share a locker, but Rachel cannot share a locker. Nita's locker cannot be adjacent to Trisha's locker. Fred must be assigned to locker 3.
question: Which one of the following is a complete and accurate list of the children who must be among those assigned to shared lockers?
options: A) Fred, Juan
B) Juan, Paul
C) Juan, Marc, Paul
D) Juan, Marc, Trisha
E) Juan, Nita, Trisha
raw_logic_programs:
s
# Declarations
children = EnumSort([Fred, Juan, Marc, Nita, Paul, Rachel, Trisha])
lockers = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5])
assigned = Function([children, lockers] -> [bool])
ForAll([c:children], And(assigned(c, c), Count([l:lockers], assigned(c, l)) == 1)) ::: each child must be assigned to exactly one locker
ForAll([l:lockers], Count([c:children], And(assigned(c, l), Or(c == Juan, c == Rachel))) == 1) ::: each shared locker must be assigned to one girl and one boy
And(assigned(Juan, 2), Not(assigned(Rachel, 2))) ::: Juan must share a locker, but Rachel cannot share a locker
Not(assigned(Nita, 4)) ::: Nita's locker cannot be adjacent to Trisha's locker
assigned(Fred, 3) ::: Fred must be assigned to locker 3

# Options
Question ::: ::: Which one of the following is a complete and accurate list of the children who must be among those assigned to shared lockers?
is_sat(Or(assigned(Fred, 2), assigned(Juan, 2))) ::: (A)
is_sat(Or(assigned(Juan, 2), assigned(Marc, 2))) ::: (B)
is_sat(Or(assigned(Juan, 2), assigned(Marc, 2), assigned(Paul, 2))) ::: (C)
is_sat(Or(assigned(Juan, 2), assigned(Marc, 2), assigned(Trisha, 2))) ::: (D)
is_sat(Or(assigned(Juan, 2), assigned(Nita, 2), assigned(Trisha, 2))) ::: (E)
------

If neither type of jazz is on sale, then new pop is. If either type of rap is on sale, then no soul is.
question: If exactly four of the five types of used CDs are the only CDs on sale, then which one of the following could be true?
options: A) Used jazz is not on sale.
B) Used opera is not on sale.
C) Used rap is not on sale.
D) Neither type of jazz is on sale.
E) Neither type of rap and neither type of soul is on sale.
raw_logic_programs:

cds = EnumSort([new_jazz, new_opera, new_pop, new_rap, new_soul, used_jazz, used_opera, used_pop, used_rap, used_soul])
on_sale = Function([cds] -> [bool])
ForAll([c:cds], And(on_sale(c) == True, on_sale(c) == False))

# Constraints
on_sale(used_pop) ::: Used pop is on sale
Not(on_sale(new_opera)) ::: new opera is not

Implies(on_sale(new_jazz), Not(on_sale(rap))) ::: If both types of jazz are on sale, then no rap is
Implies(Not(on_sale(new_jazz)), on_sale(new_pop)) ::: If neither type of jazz is on sale, then new pop is
Implies(Or(on_sale(used_rap), on_sale(used_soul)), Not(on_sale(rap))) ::: If either type of rap is on sale, then no soul is

context: During a single week, from Monday through Friday, tours will be conducted of a company's three divisions—Operations, Production, and Sales. Exactly five tours will be conducted that week, one each day. The schedule of tours for the week must conform to the following restrictions: Each division is toured at least once. The Operations division is not toured on Monday. The Production division is not toured on Wednesday. The Sales division is toured on two consecutive days, and on no other days. If the Operations division is toured on Thursday, then the Production division is toured on Friday.
question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true of the week's tour schedule?
options: A) The division that is toured on Monday is also toured on Tuesday.
B) The division that is toured on Monday is also toured on Friday.
C) The division that is toured on Tuesday is also toured on Thursday.
D) The division that is toured on Wednesday is also toured on Friday.
E) The division that is toured on Thursday is also toured on Friday.
raw_logic_programs:
(A)
# Declarations
days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday])
divisions = EnumSort([Operations, Production, Sales])
tours = Function([days, divisions] -> [bool])
ForAll([d:days], tours(d, Operations) == tours(d, Production) == tours(d, Sales)) ::: each division is toured at least once
Not(tours(Monday, Operations)) ::: the Operations division is not toured on Monday
Not(tours(Wednesday, Production)) ::: the Production division is not toured on Wednesday
ForAll([d:days], Implies(tours(d, Sales), Or(d == Tuesday, d == Wednesday))) ::: the Sales division is toured on two consecutive days, and on no other days
Implies(tours(Thursday, Operations), tours(Friday, Production)) ::: if the Operations division is toured on Thursday, then the Production division is toured on Friday

# Options
Question ::: ::: Which one of the following CANNOT be true of the week's tour schedule?
is_valid(ForAll([d:days], tours(d, Operations) == tours(d, Tuesday))) ::: (A)
is_valid(ForAll([d:days], tours(d, Operations) == tours(d, Friday))) ::: (B)
is_valid(ForAll([d:days], tours(d, Tuesday) == tours(d, Thursday))) ::: (C)
is_valid(ForAll([d:days], tours(d, Wednesday) == tours(d, Friday))) ::: (D)
is_valid(ForAll([d:days], tours(d, Thursday) == tours(d, Friday))) ::: (E)

songs = EnumSort([Night_s_All_Right, Question_Man, Rhino_Rock, Sammy])
instruments = EnumSort([flute, guitar, harmonica, keyboard])
performed = Function([songs, instruments] -> [int])
ForAll([s:songs, i:instruments], And(1 <= performed(s, i), performed(s, i) <= 4))

# Constraints
ForAll([s:songs], Not(performed(s, flute))) ::: The first song performed is not performed on the flute
Implies(performed(Sammy, keyboard), performed(Rhino_Rock, harmonica)) ::: If "Sammy" is performed on the keyboard, then "Rhino Rock" is performed on the harmonica
Implies(performed(Question_Man, keyboard), performed(Night_s_All_Right, flute)) ::: If "Question Man" is performed on the keyboard, then "Night's All Right" is performed on the flute
And(performed(Rhino_Rock, keyboard) < performed(Night_s_All_Right), performed(Night_s_All_Right) < performed(Sammy)) ::: the song performed on the keyboard immediately follows "Rhino Rock" and immediately precedes "Night's All Right"

# Options
Question ::: ::: Which one of the following could be true?
is_sat(ForAll([s:songs], performed(s, keyboard) < performed(Question_Man, s))) ::: (A)
is_sat(ForAll([s:songs], performed(Night_s_All_Right, s) < performed(s, keyboard))) ::: (B)
is_sat(ForAll([s:songs], performed(Question_Man, s) < performed(s, guitar))) ::: (C)
is_sat(ForAll([s:songs], performed(Rhino_Rock, s) < performed(s, harmonica))) ::: (D)
is_sat(ForAll([s:songs], performed(Sammy, s) < performed(s, guitar))) ::: (E)

context: Each of the seven members of the board of directors—Guzman, Hawking, Lepp, Miyauchi, Upchurch, Wharton, and Zhu—serves on exactly one of two committees—the finance committee or the incentives committee. Only board members serve on these committees. Committee membership is consistent with the following conditions: If Guzman serves on the finance committee, then Hawking serves on the incentives committee. If Lepp serves on the finance committee, then Miyauchi and Upchurch both serve on the incentives committee. Wharton serves on a different committee from the one on which Zhu serves. Upchurch serves on a different committee from the one on which Guzman serves. If Zhu serves on the finance committee, so does Hawking.
question: Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the members of the finance committee?
options: A) Guzman, Hawking, Miyauchi, Wharton
B) Guzman, Lepp, Zhu
C) Hawking, Miyauchi, Zhu
D) Hawking, Upchurch, Wharton, Zhu
E) Miyauchi, Upchurch, Wharton
raw_logic_programs:
(A)
# Declarations
board_members = EnumSort([Guzman, Hawking, Lepp, Miyauchi, Upchurch, Wharton, Zhu])
committees = EnumSort([finance_committee, incentives_committee])
serves_on = Function([board_members, committees] -> [bool])
ForAll([m:board_members], Count([c:committees], serves_on(m, c)) == 1) ::: each board member serves on exactly one of the two committees

# Constraints
Implies(serves_on(Guzman, finance_committee), serves_on(Hawking, incentives_committee)) ::: If Guzman serves on the finance committee, then Hawking serves on the incentives committee
Implies(serves_on(Lepp, finance_committee), And(serves_on(Miyauchi, incentives_committee), serves_on(Upchurch, incentives_committee))) ::: If Lepp serves on the finance committee, then Miyauchi and Upchurch both serve on the incentives committee
serves_on(Wharton, SetDiff([finance_committee, incentives_committee], {serves_on(Zhu, _)})) ::: Wharton serves on a different committee from the one on which Zhu serves
serves_on(Upchurch, SetDiff([finance_committee, incentives_committee], {serves_on(Guzman, _)})) ::: Upchurch serves on a different committee from the one on which Guzman serves
Implies(serves_on(Zhu, finance_committee), serves_on(Hawking, finance_committee)) ::: If Zhu serves on the finance committee, so does Hawking

# Options
Question ::: ::: Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the members of the finance committee?
is_sat(ForAll([m:board_members], Implies(serves_on(m, finance_committee), m == Guzman))) ::: (A)
is_sat(ForAll([m:board_members], Implies(serves_on(m, finance_committee), m == Lepp))) ::: (B)
is_sat(ForAll([m:board_members], Implies(serves_on(m, finance_committee), m == Hawking))) ::: (C)
is_sat(ForAll([m:board_members], Implies(serves_on(m, finance_committee), m == Upchurch))) ::: (D)
is_sat(ForAll([m:board_members], Implies(serves_on(m, finance_committee), m == Wharton))) ::: (E)

context: Eight people—Fiona, George, Harriet, Ingrid, Karl, Manuel, Olivia, and Peter—are sitting, evenly spaced, around a circular picnic table. Any two of them are said to be sitting directly across from one another if and only if there are exactly three other people sitting between them, counting in either direction around the table. The following conditions apply: Fiona sits directly across from George. Harriet sits immediately next to neither Fiona nor Karl. Ingrid sits immediately next to, and immediately clockwise from, Olivia.
question: Which one of the following could be the order in which four of the people are seated, with no one else seated between them, counting clockwise around the table?
options: A) George, Peter, Karl, Fiona
B) Harriet, Olivia, Ingrid, Karl
C) Ingrid, Fiona, Peter, Manuel
D) Olivia, Manuel, Karl, George
E) Peter, Harriet, Karl, Fiona

# Declarations
people = EnumSort([Fiona, George, Harriet, Ingrid, Karl, Manuel, Olivia, Peter])
sits_directly_across_from = Function([people, people] -> [bool])
sits_next_to = Function([people, people] -> [bool])
sits_clockwise_from = Function([people, people] -> [bool])

The judicial appointments will conform to the following conditions: Li must be appointed to the appellate court. Kurtz must be appointed to the trial court. Hamadi cannot be appointed to the same court as Perkins.
question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true?
options: A) Jefferson and McDonnell are both appointed to the appellate court.
B) Jefferson and McDonnell are both appointed to the trial court.
C) McDonnell and Ortiz are both appointed to the trial court.
D) McDonnell and Perkins are both appointed to the appellate court.
E) McDonnell and Perkins are both appointed to the trial court.
raw_logic_programs:
e
# Declarations
candidates = EnumSort([Hamadi, Jefferson, Kurtz, Li, McDonnell, Ortiz, Perkins])
appointed = Function([candidates] -> [int])
ForAll([c:candidates], And(1 <= appointed(c), appointed(c) <= 7))
courts = EnumSort([appellate_court, trial_court])
appointed_to = Function([candidates, courts] -> [bool])
ForAll([c:candidates], And(appointed_to(c, appellate_court), Count([c2:candidates], appointed_to(c2, appellate_court)) <= 3)) ::: there are three open positions on the appellate court
ForAll([c:candidates], And(appointed_to(c, trial_court), Count([c2:candidates], appointed_to(c2, trial_court)) <= 6)) ::: and six open positions on the trial court

# Constraints
appointed_to(Li, appellate_court) ::: Li must be appointed to the appellate court
appointed_to(Kurtz, trial_court) ::: Kurtz must be appointed to the trial court
ForAll([c:candidates], Implies(appointed_to(c, appellate_court), Not(appointed_to(Perkins, appellate_court)))) ::: Hamadi cannot be appointed to the same court as Perkins

# Options
Question ::: ::: Which one of the following CANNOT be true?
is_sat(And(appointed(Jefferson) == 1, appointed(McDonnell) == 1, appointed_to(Jefferson, appellate_court), appointed_to(McDonnell, appellate_court))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(appointed(Jefferson) == 1, appointed(McDonnell) == 1, appointed_to(Jefferson, trial_court), appointed_to(McDonnell, trial_court))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(appointed(McDonnell) == 1, appointed(Ortiz) == 1, appointed_to(McDonnell, trial_court), appointed_to(Ortiz, trial_court))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(appointed(McDonnell) == 1, appointed(Perkins) == 1, appointed_to(McDonnell, appellate_court), appointed_to(Perkins, appellate_court))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(appointed(McDonnell) == 1, appointed(Perkins) == 1, appointed_to(McDonnell, trial_court), appointed_to(Perkins, trial_court))) ::: (E)

context: A florist is filling a customer's order for three bouquets—bouquet 1, bouquet 2, and bouquet 3. Each of the bouquets is to be composed of one or more of five kinds of flowers—lilies, peonies, roses, snapdragons, and tulips—subject to the following conditions: Bouquets 1 and 3 cannot have any kind of flower in common. Bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common. Bouquet 3 must have snapdragons. If a bouquet has lilies, that bouquet must also have roses but cannot have snapdragons. If a bouquet has tulips, that bouquet must also have peonies.
question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true?
options: A) Lilies and roses are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 1.
B) Peonies and tulips are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 1.
C) Lilies, peonies, and roses are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 2.
D) Peonies, roses, and snapdragons are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 2.
E) Peonies, snapdragons, and tulips are the only kinds of flowers in bouquet 3.
raw_logic_programs:
s
# Declarations
bouquets = EnumSort([bouquet_1, bouquet_2, bouquet_3])
flowers = EnumSort([lilies, peonies, roses, snapdragons, tulips])
has = Function([bouquets, flowers] -> [bool])
ForAll([b:bouquets], Count([f:flowers], has(b, f)) >= 1) ::: each bouquet has at least one kind of flower
And(ForAll([f:flowers], Implies(has(bouquet_1, f), has(bouquet_1, roses))), Implies(has(bouquet_1, lilies), Not(has(bouquet_1, snapdragons)))) ::: if a bouquet has lilies, that bouquet must also have roses but cannot have snapdragons
And(ForAll([f:flowers], Implies(has(bouquet_2, f), has(bouquet_2, peonies))), Implies(has(bouquet_2, tulips), has(bouquet_2, peonies))) ::: if a bouquet has tulips, that bouquet must also have peonies
And(has(bouquet_3, snapdragons), Count([f:flowers], And(has(bouquet_3, f), Not(has(bouquet_2, f)))) == 2) ::: bouquet 3 must have snapdragons
And(Not(has(bouquet_1, f)), Not(has(bouquet_3, f))) ::: bouquets 1 and 3 cannot have any kind of flower in common
And(has(bouquet_2, f), has(bouquet_3, f)) ::: bouquets 2 and 3 must have exactly two kinds of flowers in common

# Options
Question ::: ::: Which one of the following CANNOT be true?
is_exception(ForAll([f:flowers], has(bouquet_1, f))) ::: (A)
is_exception(ForAll([f:flowers], has(bouquet_1, f))) ::: (B)
is_exception(ForAll([f:flowers], has(bouquet_2, f))) ::: (C)
is_exception(ForAll([f:flowers], has(bouquet_2, f))) ::: (D)
is_exception(ForAll([f:flowers], has(bouquet_3, f))) ::: (E)

question: If the hickory is planted on lot 2, then which one of the following trees must be planted on lot 3?
options: A) the larch

ForAll([t:trees], And(planted(t, 1), planted(t, 2), planted(t, 3))) ::: each tree must be planted on exactly one of three lots

Or(planted(maple, 2), planted(oak, 2)) ::: either the maple or the oak, but not both, is planted on lot 2
Count([t:trees], planted(t, 3)) > Count([t:trees], planted(t, 1)) ::: More trees are planted on lot 3 than on lot 1
